2 SUMMARY OF FEATURES AMIGO is the first multiplatform (Windows and Linux) environment which covers all the steps of the iterative identification procedure (Balsa-Canto et al.,
2 SUMMARY OF FEATURES AMIGO is the first multiplatform (Windows and Linux) environment which covers all the steps of the iterative identification procedure (Balsa-Canto et al.,
Implementations of the methods are available both for MATLAB and FORTRAN (the latter allows a significant reduction of computation times).
Implementations of the methods are available both for MATLAB and FORTRAN (the latter allows a significant reduction of computation times).

The server side is arranged in four modules: the Preprocessor that generates MATLAB or FORTRAN codes, performs the mex of files when required; the tasks SModel, Sobs, SData, LRank, GRank, PE, ContourP, RIdent and OED that correspond to different steps in the model identification loop; the Kernel that performs the numerical computations and the Postprocessor that post-processes the results to generate output reports, structures and figures.

The server side is arranged in four modules: the Preprocessor that generates MATLAB or FORTRAN codes, performs the mex of files when required; the tasks SModel, Sobs, SData, LRank, GRank, PE, ContourP, RIdent and OED that correspond to different steps in the model identification loop; the Kernel that performs the numerical computations and the Postprocessor that post-processes the results to generate output reports, structures and figures.

The toolbox has been implemented in MATLAB, but it also offers the possibility to automatically generate compiled FORTRAN models that AMIGO will link to FORTRAN initial value problem (IVP) solvers, substantially increasing computational efficiency.

Results: LS BAM 1.1 includes 90 goals and 61 people and groups within Use Case and Activity Unified Modeling Language (UML) Diagrams.
Availability and Implementation: The LS BAM is freely available as UML, PDF and HTML (https://wiki.nci.nih.gov/x/OFNyAQ).

LS research activities are decomposed in a top-down approach; this UML Use Case Diagram subset shows the four most general use cases, as ovals, that represent the activities that life scientists undertake.
